title: My Child Is Accurate But Slow at Math – Is That a Problem?
description: When mathematical accuracy comes at the cost of speed, and how to find the right balance.

content.intro: Your child gets math problems right – but takes forever. They're not struggling with concepts, just pace. Should you push for speed?

sections.text: Accuracy matters more than speed. A child who understands math deeply and gets answers right has a solid foundation. Many slow, accurate kids become strong mathematicians.
Unfortunately, real-world constraints make speed relevant:

items: Mental math situations require quick responses
Math anxiety can develop from always being last

rows: Won't move on until absolutely certain

sections.text: How to Build Speed Without Sacrificing Accuracy
The biggest speed killer is not having instant recall of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division facts. Practice until these are reflexive, not calculated.
Introduce time as information, not pressure. "Let's see how long this takes" rather than "You have 5 minutes." Build awareness before building pressure.
Personal bests are motivating. "You did 10 problems in 8 minutes last week. Can you do it in 7 minutes this week?" Progress, not comparison.
For perfectionists: "What's your best guess? Write it and move on." Sometimes getting it wrong isn't catastrophic.
Kids who trust their abilities don't need to triple-check. Confidence comes from consistent practice and success.
The goal is fluency, not frantic speed. A fluent math student is accurate AND reasonably quick – not because they rush, but because the basics are automatic.

faq.question: Should I time homework?
faq.answer: Not generally. But you can note how long things take and set reasonable limits. If homework is taking 2 hours when it should take 30 minutes, that's information to share with the teacher.

faq.question: Will speed come naturally with practice?
faq.answer: Usually, yes. As concepts become more familiar and facts become automatic, speed naturally improves. But deliberate fluency practice can accelerate this.

faq.question: My child panics under time pressure. What do I do?
faq.answer: Start with no pressure and very gradually add time awareness. Build confidence first. Consider whether anxiety needs to be addressed separately.

cta.text: SoroKid builds math fluency gradually – helping accurate kids become accurate AND confident with pace.
